snippet: In interviews around the country, many Americans were sorry about what had happened and fearful of attacks at home.
abstract: Terrorist attacks in Paris resonate deeply with Americans, many of whom report attacks on European soil feel closer to home than conflicts in other places abroad; reactions range from sympathy to fear to anger and hatred.

byline.original: By JACK HEALY and RICHARD FAUSSET
byline.contributor: Jack Healy reported from Denver, and Richard Fausset from Raleigh, Miss. Reporting was contributed by Fernanda Santos from Phoenix; Mitch Smith from Chicago; Alan Blinder from Charleston, W.Va.; Frances Robles from Miami; Jess Bidgood from Boston; Ian Lovett from Los Angeles; Kirk Johnson from Seattle; and Eli Rosenberg, Ryan McCarthy, Nate Schweber, John Surico, John Broder, Emily Steel, Stephen Cooper and Jaimie Abir from New York.

lead_paragraph: In interviews around the country, many Americans were sorry about what had happened and fearful of attacks at home.

headline.main: Americans View Paris Attacks With Empathy, Fear and Resolve
headline.print_headline: Americans React to Paris Attacks With Empathy, Fear and Resolve

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
